quote: You read the stories about horses being starved at Santa Anita, but a horse can't starve at Santa Anita! I mean, there's just bags of carrots all over the place; food is everywhere. They don't starve any horses!

There's a weird trick to it. You don't want to overwhelm the first six rows. You don't want to starve the back. I could never get it.

It is precisely the permeation of the free market throughout the world that has virtually ended this scourge of famine by permitting trade between areas.
I'd rather starve than not have what I really want to eat. I'm good at preparation.

It's no different for the human race. Whether you consider yourself a gazelle or a lion, you have to run faster than others to survive.

Socialism states that you owe me something simply because I exist. Capitalism, by contrast, results in a sort of reality-forced altruism: I may not want to help you, I may dislike you, but if I don't give you a product or service you want, I will starve. Voluntary exchange is more moral than forced redistribution.
